conclusion: Analyze the velocity-time graph to determine when the objects are farthest apart.
Distance between objects is found by integrating the difference in velocities from t = 0 to t.
From t = 0 to t = t1, object A has a positive velocity while object B has a decreasing velocity.
From t = t1 to t = t2, object A continues with a constant velocity v0 while object B's velocity increases.
From t = t2 to t = t3, object A's velocity decreases linearly to zero while object B's velocity continues to increase.
From t = t3 to t = t4, object A remains stationary while object B's velocity continues to increase.
The area under the velocity-time graph represents displacement; the difference in areas gives separation.
At t = t1, object A has moved some distance while object B has moved less.
At t = t2, object A has moved further with constant velocity v0 while object B lags behind.
At t = t3, object A's velocity decreases to zero but has accumulated more distance than object B.
At t = t4, object A is stationary while object B continues to increase its velocity.
Maximum separation occurs when the difference in areas under the graphs is greatest, at t = t3.
The two objects are farthest apart at t = t3.
